item.title: About
item.description: Hardcore scientist with excellent communication skills, fast learner and critical thinker, with dedicated, detail-oriented, analytical and organized characters. My passion is to use my expertise in statistical learning and programming to deliver game-changing knowledge from data. I received my B.S. in Applied Math from Peking University, after which I started graduate training at Boston University, working in Computational Biomedicine (CBM), while jointly advised by Evan and Giovanni. Now I am about to enter (hopefully) the final year of my PhD.

item.title: Personal
item.description: My name, Yuqing (雨晴), is pronounced y-oo-ching. It means the sky clears up after rain. I live mainly in Boston, but sometimes in Berkeley California too, where my husband, Ronghang, lives and works. My research and study take up most of my time. But whenever possible, I would gather and chat with my friends, or have a nice beer while watching a good movie. My lifelong favourite movie is Cracks. I’m a fun of J-pops, for example, Akane Sasu by Aimer; and popular Chinese ballads, some examples include An He Qiao by Dongye Song (安和桥-宋冬野) and Wu Wen by Mao Buyi (无问-毛不易).

item.title: Projects
item.description: Completed Lung cancer classification from CT scan images using deep CNNs 2017 Data Science Bowl Kaggle Competition Implemented U-Net with Python and Tensorflow according to literature for nodule segmentation Developed deep convolutional neural networks for lung cancer classification Applied batch normalization, drop-out layers, and tuned parameters to improve prediction accuracy Augmented training data by random cropping and merging the training set with images from public databases of CT scans Achieved performance comparable to top-50 out of nearly 2000 participating teams A multivariate Gaussian Network model for detection of multiple perturbations in gene regulartory networks

item.title: Publications
item.description: Journal Papers 2019 McQuerry, J. A. , Jenkins, D. F. , Yost, S. E. , Zhang, Y., Schmolze, D., Johnson, W. E., Yuan, Y., & Bild, A. Pathway activity profiling of growth factor receptor network and stemness pathways differentiates metaplastic breast cancer histological subtypes. (under review in BMC Cancer) 2018 Zhang, Y., Bernau, C., Parmigiani, G., & Waldron, L. (2018). The impact of different sources of heterogeneity on loss of accuracy from genomic prediction models.

item.title: Software
item.description: R/Bioconductor packages simulatorZ Zhang Y, Bernau C, Waldron L (2018). simulatorZ: Simulator for Collections of Independent Genomic Data Sets. R package version 1.16.0. reference-batch ComBat Leek JT, Johnson WE, Parker HS, Fertig EJ, Jaffe AE, Storey JD, Zhang Y, Torres LC (2019). sva: Surrogate Variable Analysis. R package version 3.30.1.

item.title: DESCEND - Gene expression distribution deconvolution in scRNA-seq
item.description: Microarray and bulk RNA-seq data measure. Background knowledge Goal of this paper Methods behind DESCEND Results Model evaluation Case studies Effect of cell size on differential non-zero mean and fraction analysis DESCEND improves accuracy of cell type identification, by selecting better highly variable genes Take-home messages When all across-cell differences are accounted for, Poisson distribution is sufficient to capture technical noise in UMI-based scRNA-seq counts.
